Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement for permanent residents
Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD reasonably determined that the Applicant failed to meet residency obligations under IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.28
Application_Facts: Applicant spent only 312 days in Canada over five years and worked for Conares Canada Ltd., which was deemed a business of convenience due to lack of ongoing operations in Canada
Decision_Outcome: IAD's decision was reasonable; application for judicial review dismissed
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of IAD's dismissal of appeal against visa officer's determination
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to accumulate required 730 days of physical presence in Canada and relied on overseas employment with a Canadian company lacking substantive operations
Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to IADâ€™s factual findings, procedural fairness, factor analysis, and legal interpretation
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Assessment_Factor: Duration of physical presence in Canada, legitimacy of overseas employment by Canadian business
Credibility_Assessment: IAD found Conares Canada Ltd. to be a business of convenience
Evidence_Used: Records of time spent in Canada, employment records with Conares Canada Ltd.
Application_Basis: Permanent resident seeking to maintain status through physical presence or qualifying employment abroad
Evidence_Assessed: Travel records, corporate documentation of Conares Canada Ltd.'s operations
Relief_Sought: Overturning of IAD decision and reinstatement of residency compliance
Governing_Rule: Under IRPA s.28, permanent residents must be physically present in Canada for at least 730 days over five years or employed full-time by a Canadian business abroad
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating genuine operations of Conares Canada Ltd. in Canada
Harm_Assessment: Loss of permanent resident status due to non-compliance with residency obligation
Cause_Description: Applicant challenged IAD's dismissal of his appeal against visa officer's determination of residency obligation breach
Evidence_Handling: IAD evaluated travel history and employment conditions to assess compliance
Evidence_Issues: Questionable legitimacy of overseas employment arrangement with Canadian company
Residency_Compliance: Only 312 days physically present in Canada over five-year period
Evidence_Assessment: IAD assessed credibility of employment relationship and physical presence records
Decision_Rationale: The IAD reasonably concluded that the applicant did not meet the residency requirement and that the overseas employment did not qualify under IRPA s.28
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient proof of active Canadian business operations supporting overseas employment exemption
